description: From Middle English birlen, from Old English byrelian (“to give or serve a drink to”), from byrele (“cup-bearer, steward, butler”), from Proto-Germanic *burilijaz (“carrier, manservant”), from *burjô (“descendant, son”), from *beraną (“to bear, carry”). Related to Old English byre (“son, offspring, youth”). More at bear.

verbs.description: birle (third-person singular simple present birles, present participle birling, simple past and past participle birled)

examples: She has birld in him Young Hunting / The good ale and the beer, / Till he was as fou drunken / As any wild-wood steer.

entries.meaning: (Scotland, obsolete) To drink deeply or excessively; carouse.
examples: They birled, they birled at Annies[sic] wake / The white bread and the wine, / And ere the morn at that same time / At his they birled the same.
